questions.question: If <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: First, solve for <math><mi>x</mi></math>. Subtract 9 from both sides of <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn></math> to get <math><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn></math>. Divide by 4 to get <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. Then substitute <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math> into the expression <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></math>: <math><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>11</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: You can solve for x first, or notice relationships between expressions. However, finding x explicitly is often the safest method.

questions.question: The graph of the function <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></math> is shown in the xy-plane. What are the coordinates of the vertex of the graph?
questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='300' viewBox='0 0 300 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><defs><marker id='arrow' viewBox='0 0 10 10' refX='5' refY='5' markerWidth='6' markerHeight='6' orient='auto-start-reverse'><path d='M 0 0 L 10 5 L 0 10 z' /></marker></defs><line x1='150' y1='290' x2='150' y2='10' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><line x1='10' y1='150' x2='290' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><text x='280' y='140' font-family='Arial' font-size='12'>x</text><text x='160' y='20' font-family='Arial' font-size='12'>y</text><path d='M 50 250 Q 150 -150 250 250' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' fill='none' transform='translate(60, 40) scale(0.6)' /><circle cx='210' cy='110' r='3' fill='red' /><text x='215' y='105' font-family='Arial' font-size='12'>(3, 2)</text><line x1='150' y1='110' x2='210' y2='110' stroke='black' stroke-dasharray='4' opacity='0.5'/><line x1='210' y1='150' x2='210' y2='110' stroke='black' stroke-dasharray='4' opacity='0.5'/><text x='205' y='165' font-family='Arial' font-size='10'>3</text><text x='135' y='115' font-family='Arial' font-size='10'>2</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: Graph of a parabola opening upwards with its minimum point (vertex) clearly marked at coordinates x=3 and y=2.
questions.explanation: The vertex form of a quadratic equation is <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi></math>, where <math><mo>(</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo></math> is the vertex. Comparing <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></math> to the standard form, we identify <math><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math> and <math><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. Therefore, the vertex is at <math><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember that in vertex form, the x-coordinate of the vertex has the opposite sign of the term inside the parenthesis, while the y-coordinate keeps the sign of the constant term.

questions.question: The scatterplot shows the relationship between variable <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math> and variable <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi></math>. Which of the following equations best models the line of best fit shown in the graph?
questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='300' viewBox='0 0 300 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='300' height='300' fill='white' /><defs><marker id='arrow' viewBox='0 0 10 10' refX='5' refY='5' markerWidth='6' markerHeight='6' orient='auto-start-reverse'><path d='M 0 0 L 10 5 L 0 10 z' /></marker></defs><line x1='40' y1='260' x2='40' y2='20' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><line x1='40' y1='260' x2='280' y2='260' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><text x='270' y='250' font-family='serif' font-style='italic' font-size='12'>x</text><text x='25' y='30' font-family='serif' font-style='italic' font-size='12'>y</text><line x1='40' y1='260' x2='240' y2='60' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' /><circle cx='80' cy='210' r='3' fill='black' opacity='0.7'/><circle cx='120' cy='190' r='3' fill='black' opacity='0.7'/><circle cx='160' cy='140' r='3' fill='black' opacity='0.7'/><circle cx='200' cy='110' r='3' fill='black' opacity='0.7'/><circle cx='220' cy='90' r='3' fill='black' opacity='0.7'/><text x='25' y='275' font-size='10'>0</text><text x='75' y='275' font-size='10'>2</text><text x='115' y='275' font-size='10'>4</text><text x='155' y='275' font-size='10'>6</text><text x='195' y='275' font-size='10'>8</text><text x='235' y='275' font-size='10'>10</text><text x='25' y='225' font-size='10'>2</text><text x='25' y='185' font-size='10'>4</text><text x='25' y='145' font-size='10'>6</text><text x='25' y='105' font-size='10'>8</text><text x='20' y='65' font-size='10'>10</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A scatterplot with axes labeled x and y, both ranging from 0 to 10. A blue line of best fit starts at the origin (0,0) and passes exactly through the point (10,10). Scatter points are distributed closely around this line.
questions.explanation: To determine the equation of the line, we identify two points on the line: the origin <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></math> and the point <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Calculating the slope <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>m</mi></math>: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>10</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>10</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>. Since the <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi></math>-intercept is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>0</mn></math>, the equation is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mi>x</mi></math>, or simply <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='300' viewBox='0 0 300 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='300' height='300' fill='white' /><defs><marker id='arrow' viewBox='0 0 10 10' refX='5' refY='5' markerWidth='6' markerHeight='6' orient='auto-start-reverse'><path d='M 0 0 L 10 5 L 0 10 z' /></marker></defs><line x1='40' y1='260' x2='40' y2='20' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><line x1='40' y1='260' x2='280' y2='260' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><text x='270' y='250' font-family='serif' font-style='italic' font-size='12'>x</text><text x='25' y='30' font-family='serif' font-style='italic' font-size='12'>y</text><line x1='40' y1='260' x2='240' y2='60' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' opacity='0.3'/><circle cx='40' cy='260' r='4' fill='red'/><circle cx='240' cy='60' r='4' fill='red'/><line x1='40' y1='260' x2='240' y2='260' stroke='red' stroke-dasharray='4' /><line x1='240' y1='260' x2='240' y2='60' stroke='red' stroke-dasharray='4' /><text x='130' y='275' fill='red' font-size='12'>Run = 10</text><text x='245' y='160' fill='red' font-size='12'>Rise = 10</text><text x='80' y='100' fill='red' font-size='12'>Slope = 10/10 = 1</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The explanation chart highlights the slope triangle for the line of best fit. It shows a horizontal run of 10 units (from x=0 to x=10) and a vertical rise of 10 units (from y=0 to y=10), confirming the slope is 1.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify two distinct points on the line of best fit (like the intercepts or integer coordinates) to calculate the slope: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mrow><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow></mfrac></math>.

questions.question: Which of the following expressions is equivalent to <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>4</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>16</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: The expression <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>4</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>16</mn></math> is a difference of squares: <math><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><msup><mn>4</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. The term <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn></math> is also a difference of squares and factors further into <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Thus, the fully factored form is <math><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Always check if factors can be factored further, especially with difference of squares patterns.

questions.question: The graph of the linear function <math><mi>f</mi></math> passes through the points <math><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></math> and <math><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Which equation defines <math><mi>f</mi></math>?
questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='300' viewBox='0 0 300 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><defs><marker id='arrow' viewBox='0 0 10 10' refX='5' refY='5' markerWidth='6' markerHeight='6' orient='auto-start-reverse'><path d='M 0 0 L 10 5 L 0 10 z' /></marker></defs><line x1='150' y1='290' x2='150' y2='10' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><line x1='10' y1='150' x2='290' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><line x1='150' y1='50' x2='230' y2='90' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' stroke-linecap='round' /><circle cx='150' cy='50' r='3' fill='red' /><text x='160' y='50' font-family='Arial' font-size='12'>(0, 5)</text><circle cx='230' cy='90' r='3' fill='red' /><text x='240' y='90' font-family='Arial' font-size='12'>(4, 3)</text><text x='280' y='140' font-family='Arial' font-size='12'>x</text><text x='160' y='20' font-family='Arial' font-size='12'>y</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A line graphed on Cartesian axes passing through the y-intercept at (0, 5) and the point (4, 3). The line slopes downwards.
questions.explanation: First, find the slope <math><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mrow><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mn>4</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>. The y-intercept is given as the point <math><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></math>, so <math><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. The equation is <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When a y-intercept is explicitly given, immediately calculate the slope to select the correct linear equation.

questions.question: What is the positive solution to the equation <math><mn>3</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>12</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>36</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Divide the entire equation by 3 to simplify: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Factor the quadratic: <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. The solutions are <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math> and <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. The positive solution is 6.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Simplify quadratic equations by dividing by the greatest common divisor of the coefficients before factoring.

questions.question: In a right triangle, angle <math><mi>X</mi></math> and angle <math><mi>Y</mi></math> are acute angles. If <math><mi>sin</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>X</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>5</mn><mn>13</mn></mfrac></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>cos</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>Y</mi><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation: In a right triangle, the acute angles are complementary (they sum to 90 degrees). For complementary angles <math><mi>X</mi></math> and <math><mi>Y</mi></math>, the identity <math><mi>sin</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>X</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>Y</mi><mo>)</mo></math> holds true. Therefore, <math><mi>cos</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>Y</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>5</mn><mn>13</mn></mfrac></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Recall the co-function identity: sine of an angle equals cosine of its complement.

questions.question: The population <math><mi>P</mi></math> of a town <math><mi>t</mi></math> years after 2010 is modeled by the function <math><mi>P</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>12000</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>1.03</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mi>t</mi></msup></math>. Which statement best describes the population change?

options.A: The population increases by 3% each year.
options.B: The population increases by 103% each year.
options.C: The population increases by 3 people each year.
options.D: The population increases by 1.03 people each year.

questions.explanation: The exponential growth model is <math><mi>P</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>r</mi><msup><mo>)</mo><mi>t</mi></msup></math>. Here, the base is <math><mn>1.03</mn></math>, which can be written as <math><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>0.03</mn></math>. This represents a growth rate <math><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.03</mn></math>, or 3%.
questions.score_improvement_tip: In exponential models of the form a(b)^x, if b > 1, the growth rate is (b - 1) expressed as a percentage.

questions.question: Which of the following inequalities is represented by the shaded region in the graph?
questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='300' viewBox='0 0 300 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><defs><marker id='arrow' viewBox='0 0 10 10' refX='5' refY='5' markerWidth='6' markerHeight='6' orient='auto-start-reverse'><path d='M 0 0 L 10 5 L 0 10 z' /></marker><pattern id='hatch' patternUnits='userSpaceOnUse' width='8' height='8' patternTransform='rotate(45)'><path d='M0,0 L0,8' stroke='#000000' stroke-width='1' opacity='0.2'/></pattern></defs><rect x='0' y='0' width='300' height='300' fill='white' /><polygon points='0,200 300,100 300,300 0,300' fill='url(#hatch)' /><line x1='150' y1='290' x2='150' y2='10' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><line x1='10' y1='150' x2='290' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><text x='280' y='140' font-family='serif' font-style='italic' font-size='12'>x</text><text x='160' y='20' font-family='serif' font-style='italic' font-size='12'>y</text><line x1='0' y1='200' x2='300' y2='100' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='8,5' /><circle cx='150' cy='150' r='3' fill='black'/><text x='135' y='165' font-size='10'>0</text><line x1='240' y1='145' x2='240' y2='155' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='235' y='170' font-size='10'>3</text><line x1='145' y1='120' x2='155' y2='120' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='130' y='125' font-size='10'>1</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A graph of a linear inequality on the xy-plane. A dashed line passes through the origin (0,0) and the point (3,1), indicating a slope of 1/3. The region below the dashed line is shaded with diagonal hash marks.
questions.explanation: First, find the equation of the boundary line. The line passes through the origin <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></math> and passes through <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. The slope <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>m</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math>. The line is dashed, which implies a strict inequality (< or >). Finally, since the shaded region is **below** the line, the inequality is 'less than'. Thus, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>y</mi><mo><</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mi>x</mi></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='300' viewBox='0 0 300 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect x='0' y='0' width='300' height='300' fill='white' /><defs><marker id='arrow' viewBox='0 0 10 10' refX='5' refY='5' markerWidth='6' markerHeight='6' orient='auto-start-reverse'><path d='M 0 0 L 10 5 L 0 10 z' /></marker></defs><line x1='150' y1='290' x2='150' y2='10' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><line x1='10' y1='150' x2='290' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><text x='280' y='140' font-family='serif' font-style='italic' font-size='12'>x</text><text x='160' y='20' font-family='serif' font-style='italic' font-size='12'>y</text><line x1='0' y1='200' x2='300' y2='100' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='8,5' /><circle cx='240' cy='120' r='3' fill='blue'/><text x='230' y='110' font-size='10' fill='blue'>(3, 1)</text><path d='M150 150 L240 150 L240 120' stroke='red' stroke-width='1' fill='none'/><text x='195' y='165' font-size='10' fill='red'>Run = 3</text><text x='245' y='140' font-size='10' fill='red'>Rise = 1</text><circle cx='240' cy='210' r='4' fill='green'/><text x='250' y='210' font-size='10' fill='green' font-weight='bold'>Test Point (3, -2)</text><text x='200' y='250' font-size='12' fill='green'>-2 < 1/3(3)</text><text x='200' y='270' font-size='12' fill='green'>TRUE</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The explanation graph shows the slope triangle (rise 1, run 3) to confirm the slope is 1/3. It also highlights a test point (3, -2) located in the shaded region. Substituting these coordinates into the inequality y < 1/3x results in -2 < 1, which is a true statement, confirming the correct region.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Check the line type first: dashed means strict (< or >), solid means inclusive (≤ or ≥). Then pick a test point in the shaded area (like (3, -2)) to see which inequality holds true.

questions.skill: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
questions.question: If <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math> and <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>11</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Add the two equations together: <math><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>11</mn></math>, which simplifies to <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn></math>, so <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. Substitute <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math> into <math><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>11</mn></math> to get <math><mn>5</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>11</mn></math>, so <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>. The value of <math><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></math> is <math><mn>5</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>30</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When coefficients of a variable are opposites (like -y and +y), adding the equations is the most efficient method.

questions.question: In the equation <math><mn>2</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, <math><mi>k</mi></math> is a constant. If the equation has no real solutions, which of the following could be the value of <math><mi>k</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: A quadratic equation has no real solutions if its discriminant, <math><msup><mi>b</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>a</mi><mi>c</mi></math>, is negative. Here <math><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>, <math><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn></math>, and <math><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>k</mi></math>. The discriminant is <math><mo>(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>k</mi></math>. For no real solutions, <math><mn>16</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>k</mi><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, which implies <math><mn>16</mn><mo><</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>k</mi></math> or <math><mn>2</mn><mo><</mo><mi>k</mi></math>. The only option greater than 2 is 3.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember the discriminant conditions: positive for 2 real solutions, zero for 1, and negative for 0 real solutions.

questions.skill: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
questions.question:
The system of equations below has infinitely many solutions. What is the value of a+b?
ax+8y=123x+by=6
questions.explanation: For a system to have infinitely many solutions, the equations must be equivalent. Multiply the second equation by 2 to match the constant term of the first: <math><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>)</mo></math>, which gives <math><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>b</mi><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>. Comparing coefficients with <math><mi>a</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>, we see <math><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math> and <math><mn>2</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math> (so <math><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math>). Therefore, <math><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: If a linear system has infinitely many solutions, one equation is a scalar multiple of the other.

questions.question: What is the solution set of the equation <math><msqrt><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>18</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Square both sides: <math><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>18</mn><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. Rearrange to <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>18</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Factor: <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Solutions are <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math> and <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. Check for extraneous solutions: If <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></math>, <math><msqrt><mn>3</mn><mo>(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>18</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mn>9</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>, but the right side is <math><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. Since <math><mn>3</mn><mo>≠</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></math>, <math><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></math> is extraneous. If <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>, <math><msqrt><mn>18</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>18</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>, which is true. The only solution is 6.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Always plug potential solutions back into radical equations to check for extraneous roots.

questions.question: A system of equations consists of <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math> and <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math>, where <math><mi>a</mi></math> and <math><mi>b</mi></math> are constants and <math><mi>a</mi><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></math>. For which value of <math><mi>b</mi></math> will the system have exactly one real solution?
questions.explanation: Substitute <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math> into the quadratic equation: <math><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></math>, or <math><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>b</mi></math>. For there to be exactly one real solution, the quadratic term must equal zero (since <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>±</mo><msqrt><mn>0</mn></msqrt></math> is one solution). Thus, <math><mn>3</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, which implies <math><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. Visually, the vertex of the parabola <math><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>)</mo></math> must touch the line <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For a horizontal line to intersect a vertical parabola exactly once, it must pass through the parabola's vertex.

questions.question: The equation of a circle in the xy-plane is <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>c</mi></math>, where <math><mi>c</mi></math> is a constant. If the radius of the circle is 7, what is the value of <math><mi>c</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Complete the square for x and y. <math><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>16</mn></math>. This becomes <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>25</mn></math>. The standard form is <math><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>h</mi><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>k</mi><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. Given <math><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math>, <math><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>49</mn></math>. So, <math><mi>c</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>25</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>49</mn></math>, which means <math><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>24</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When completing the square, remember to add the squared half-coefficients to both sides of the equation.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: A researcher estimated the average height of a population of trees to be 15 meters with a margin of error of 1.5 meters at a 95% confidence level. Which of the following is the most appropriate conclusion?

options.A: Exactly 95% of the trees have a height between 13.5 and 16.5 meters.
options.B: The true average height of the population is likely between 13.5 and 16.5 meters.
options.C: Every sample taken will have an average height between 13.5 and 16.5 meters.
options.D: The average height of the trees is exactly 15 meters.

questions.explanation: A confidence interval provides a range of plausible values for the population parameter (mean). It does not describe individual data points or guarantee every sample mean falls in that range. It simply suggests we can be 95% confident the true mean lies within the interval <math><mn>15</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>1.5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Confidence intervals describe the population parameter (like the mean), not individual data points or sample distributions.

questions.question: What is the sum of the solutions to the equation <math><mo>|</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>|</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>14</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: Set up two equations: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>14</mn></math> and <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>14</mn></math>. Solving the first: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></math>, so <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>. Solving the second: <math><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>8</mn></math>, so <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn></math>. The sum of the solutions is <math><mn>10</mn><mo>+</mo><mo>(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For absolute value equations |ax+b|=c, the sum of solutions is -2b/a divided by the coefficient behavior, or simply solve both cases and add.

questions.question: For the equation <math><mn>4</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>12</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, where <math><mi>c</mi></math> is a constant, the equation has exactly one real solution. What is the value of <math><mi>c</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: For a quadratic to have exactly one solution, the discriminant must be zero. <math><msup><mi>b</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>a</mi><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Plugging in values: <math><mo>(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>12</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. This simplifies to <math><mn>144</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>16</mn><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Solving for <math><mi>c</mi></math>: <math><mn>16</mn><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>144</mn></math>, so <math><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: If a quadratic has exactly one solution, it is a perfect square trinomial, and the discriminant is zero.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='300' viewBox='0 0 300 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><circle cx='150' cy='150' r='100' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' fill='none'/><path d='M 150 150 L 250 150 A 100 100 0 0 0 200 63.4 Z' fill='lightgray' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><circle cx='150' cy='150' r='3' fill='black'/><text x='130' y='165' font-family='Arial' font-size='12'>O</text><text x='180' y='140' font-family='Arial' font-size='12'>60°</text><text x='200' y='165' font-family='Arial' font-size='12'>6</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A circle with center O and a shaded sector. The radius is labeled 6 and the central angle is 60 degrees.
questions.question: A circle has a radius of 6. A sector of the circle has a central angle of <math><mn>60</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. If the area of the sector is <math><mi>k</mi><mi>π</mi></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>k</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: The area of a circle is <math><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>36</mn><mi>π</mi></math>. The sector represents <math><mfrac><mn>60</mn><mn>360</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>6</mn></mfrac></math> of the circle. The area of the sector is <math><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>6</mn></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>36</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>π</mi></math>. Therefore, <math><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Sector area is a fraction of the total area: (central angle / 360) * total area.

questions.question: If <math><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>x</mi></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>5</mn><mn>6</mn></mfrac></math>, what is the integer value of the solution for <math><mi>x</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Combine the left side: <math><mfrac><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></math>. Set equal to <math><mfrac><mn>5</mn><mn>6</mn></mfrac></math> and cross-multiply: <math><mn>6</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></math>. This gives <math><mn>12</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi></math>. Rearrange to <math><mn>5</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>17</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Factor: <math><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. The solutions are <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac></math> and <math><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. The question asks for the integer value, so the answer is 3.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When solving rational equations, find a common denominator or cross-multiply to eliminate fractions, then solve the resulting polynomial equation.
